I look forward very much to the outcomes of that Occupational Health and Safety Commission, in particular some of the initial projects it is looking at at the moment, one of which is the implications of repetitive strain injury around this country.

Another area of interest of mine, of which the Government is very supportive, is the community health program. Whilst some people might argue that there has not been sufficient growth in the community health program, in the Government's first term we have had an increase in funding for the program to bring it back to the real terms of 1975. Those real terms were necessary to establish because of the cutbacks that had been allowed to occur under the seven years of Fraser Government. The community health program can expect to continue to grow in 1985 under the present Government. The Department of Community Services has been established by the Government in this term. The concern of the Labor Government is to provide community services to reach people in the community where their needs are immediate. This is an article of faith for those of us on this side of the chamber.

One policy which was implemented, which certainly earned us some brickbats on the way through, was the assets test. It is quite clear that the assets test has proved to be successful. In fact, it will recoup for the Government over $100m, instead of the predicted $30m return, in the first year. That indicates how many people in the community who had other sources of income or wealth were drawing the age pension and benefits. Even with the very generous assets test that is in place, at least some people who have sufficient income of their own will not be supported with the pension in the future, so that the pension dollar can be more appropriately allocated to those who have no other source of income than the government pension.

As people have seen the assets test established, they have discovered that many of the fears or anxieties they had about it were unreal. The complaints about the assets test at the moment are very few. They come from those people who have a particular difficulty because of, perhaps, their property arrangements or their lifestyles. The Government is very prepared to consider individual complaints under the exemption clause of the assets test. It has no intention, given the satisfactory acceptance of the assets test, of making any major changes to that test. The test is successful and apart from the money it has recouped for reallocation to more needy people it also has closed a loophole to prevent people from rearranging their moneys so as not only to be provided for in their own right but also to draw government dollars. I challenge Senator Vanstone to address that question. If those people in this country who believe so strongly in private enterprise were less prepared to take less moneys in the form of government age pensions, we would have less difficulty in providing for those people who have no other support or income.

Another area of great achievement of the Labor Government, which I am delighted will be continued, is the many initiatives and steps taken in the area of peace and disarmament. The previous Labor Government appointed Australia's first Ambassador for Disarmament to represent Australia in international fora on behalf of this country and on behalf of this Government's policies for peace and disarmament. Australia has just been elected to the United Nations Security Council with, as I understand it, one of the largest ever votes. The Government has been very actively pursuing the establishment of the comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty discussions. In fact, our Ambassador is one of the people who have worked very hard to enable those discussions to get underway again. This has been, in part, because of the considerable discussion between our Government and America on this issue. It is regarded by the Government as absolutely crucial to the whole peace and disarmament discussion. It is something this Government is totally committed to, and I think it can take considerable praise for its efforts in this area. One of the priority disarmament objectives for Australia is that the comprehensive nuclear test ban discussions be re-established and underway. It is one thing for which the Government will continue to work very strenuously. If one looks at the way the last election was run, one would have thought the Nuclear Disarmament Party was the first to think of peace and disarmament. That is a very large misrepresentation of the achievements of this Government in that area and the achievements will continue.

I turn to another area of particular interest of mine-the achievements of the Government in the area of women's affairs. Firstly, the Government introduced and enacted the Sex Discrimination Act, after one of the most remarkable debates in this place. The Opposition seemed to mount one campaign or case of drivel on top of another. We finally saw our way through that debate and the Sex Discrimination Act was passed. I know of no complaints under that legislation. I would allow there may be complaints that I have not picked up, but in all ways it seems to be a very successful piece of legislation that is well in place. In coming to office the Labor Government proceeded to ratify the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women, again a matter of considerable satisfaction. It is a step by this Government that is worthy of praise.

We now have in place an affirmative action pilot program with over 30 companies and tertiary education institutions participating. Part of that pilot project is looking at ways in which policies to redress the current discrimination against women can be overcome. I noted that Senator Vanstone talked constantly about the virtues of the adversary system. The adversary system will work satisfactorily only if the weighting on either side of the scales of justice or debate is equal or near enough to equal. The affirmative action programs are in place or being proposed by this Government, because it knows, as well as acknowledges, that the scales are not weighted equally, that there are people in this country who are discriminated against, who do not have an equal opportunity to take their case adversarily or not to the public arena. Affirmative action programs address those prior steps to allow that kind of equality before the adversaries lock. But I would not agree with Senator Vanstone that the adversary system is the be all and end all. I think the steps in the Sex Discrimination Act outlining the possibility of conciliation as a way to go are very important.

The adversary system has a long history, but I do not think it is entirely illustrious. There are many difficulties with the adversary system. There are winners and losers. I do not believe we could argue that the outcome is necessarily always for the best. The important part of that understanding is the acknowledgment of the need for affirmative action programs in various areas where people are not equally able to take their place in our society. It is a great achievement for women and it is a great achievement for affirmative action programs and for other people in our country who are currently being considered in that kind of way.

The Government established a much broader consultation with women, replacing the previous National Women's Advisory Council with the National Women's Consultative Council. It has 20 members so there is a much wider representation of groups of women from around the country. Importantly too, the Office of the Status of Women was moved to the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, acknowledging the importance this Government places on the Office of the Status of Women and its area of legislation and consideration in its policy areas. Other things can be said about the achievements of the previous Labor Government, achievements that are either in place or in train to be consolidated in the next three years of government.

I wish to conclude my remarks by turning to the importance of understanding fully what we mean by reform and what a reformist government might be about. It does not mean that, every day of the week, a new project or a new policy will be implemented or introduced. The important part of a reformist government is not only the initial steps of placing that policy or legislation through the parliaments; it is also the necessary consolidation throughout the community of those reforms. That to me, very importantly, means community education, community participation-if you like, the process of enabling people in our society to understand what those reforms are about, not only prior to their being introduced but also very much after they have been introduced.

To that end I have, hopefully, contributed to my part in taking up that process of education. One way in which I have done this, when I appreciated how few people seemed to understand about Federal parliaments, State parliaments or upper or lower Houses, was to prepare with a colleague of mine, Barbara Wiese, from South Australia, what we called the 'Upper House Tea Party'-a tea party being either the Boston Tea Party if one wishes to be political, or the Mad Hatter's Tea Party if one wants to look at farce, either of which seemed apposite to politics. We wrote a script and prepared a matching slide show. We have taken that educational program about the Senate, the upper Houses and what governments do to the people of South Australia. This year we will be doing that further for school children. We discovered the response was quite remarkable. People do not know, but the response to people not knowing is not to call them stupid but in fact to provide the information. We have found that that information provision was very well received.

I have also been asked by the Government to convene a committee to look at women and sport. We are preparing to write our report for tabling, hopefully in this session of Parliament. At least at this stage we are on time and under budget. The committee and I have travelled to every State and Territory in this country, talking with women about the problems and successes they have had in sport, and the insufficiency of finances for their facilities, for training and for coaching. We have also examined the sufficiency or insufficiency of media coverage of women's sport. The evidence is quite clear: Women in sport are currently quite disadvantaged. While I do not wish to pre-empt what the committee's report will say, I have no trouble in saying that the summary of the public evidence brought before the committee is that things must change, that they are not too good at the moment. We have also flushed out some remarkable examples of prejudice by sports writers around this country, some of which we are very grateful for because they classically illustrate the point we wanted to make-that such prejudice does still exist. We thank them for their copy and hope to include those examples in our report. It is not often that we get served up on a platter such clear illustrations of the case in point.

I think it is very important to continue the process of implementing and passing to people the necessary information and support so that the policies put in place by government are not only implemented but also understood. We have heard the effects of the fear mongering and scare tactics of the Opposition about the assets test. One of the things the Government had to do was not only deal with providing the necessary information and support about the assets test to people in this community; but also to deal with allaying the fear that was hyped up and roused by the Opposition. That kind of public rhetoric does the cause of whichever government no good at all. I think it is a very good illustration of irresponsible opposition behaviour and a very good illustration of the need of reformist governments to accept that they have to deal with that kind of nonsense from oppositions. They may have the rhetoric about how good it is we all work together, but that is not their record to this point. I do appreciate the importance of reformist governments acknowledging how difficult it is sometimes for people in the community, firstly, to cope with change and, secondly, to have the necessary information and support to understand and then respond to those changes.

The considerations of the Government this year in approaching the question of tax I think were well summarised in the editorial in one paper I read this morning. It is necessary, everybody agrees, that there should be some tax change. The tax system is insufficient, it is regressive, unfair and desperately needing of change. We ought to do something about welfare. But as the editorial said, after that there is no agreement on this matter. This Government is addressing the process of the important public discussion about the whole question of tax. While it does seem perhaps to be going on too long, worrying some people and becoming confusing, I think that is not necessarily so. It is part of a process of that language being understood by people, of the terms of economic debate being understood by a wider group in the community, and of more people being aware that matters of tax are under discussion.

I hope to make my contribution in this area by having a tax forum in South Australia where women may come and talk about tax issues, not necessarily arguing their own case-although given the way humans behave I am sure that some of them will-but, more importantly, allowing people to become used to the language of economics and tax debates, to understand what exactly this piece of tax legislation or that tax provision really is about so that the outcome of the tax summit and the propositions that the Government then puts in place by way of its tax reform will be better understood precisely because of the broad community discussion that has preceded it and, no doubt, will necessarily follow it.

I am delighted to be part of the returned Labor Government. I am delighted to take my part in the further implementation of policy that is under way at the moment and to make my contribution to the steps that are necessary to consolidate the reforms already in place. It is, and it will be, a great Labor Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to join fellow senators in congratulating the new senators whose maiden speeches we have heard in the last week or so and, hopefully without being patronising, to suggest that the enlarged Senate is also an enhanced Senate. I believe that the quality of senators joining this Parliament is indicative of a very increased interest in parliamentary activity by a range of people who have a very valuable contribution to make to our Parliament. Certainly, their maiden speeches indicate that to be the case.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I shall address several areas of concern that flow from the Governor-General's Speech, which left a lot of vacuums, many unanswered questions and many areas which seemed to have been abandoned by the Government. (Quorum formed) Before I was interrupted, I was referring to the failure of this Government to live up to its promises or to give any indication that it intends to keep some of the promises it made in the election campaign which helped it to get elected to government. Perhaps for the parliamentary and constitutional purists, constitutional reform is one of the biggest omissions. The Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, said during the election campaign in 1983 that he was going to give priority to the enactment of a national Bill of Rights. In the Governor-General's Speech on 21 April 1983 he announced that his advisers were considering a number of initiatives, including the enactment of an Australian Bill of Rights. So it was full steam ahead at that time.

What has happened since then? Senator Gareth Evans did nothing. The person who was seen throughout Australia as the one who was most likely to get a Bill of Rights before this Parliament and before the people of Australia for a referendum was able to achieve nothing. One would think that there is no lower point than nothing. However, it would appear that the new Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, proposes not even to attempt to activate his Labor Party contemporaries to get them moving on a Bill of Rights for Australia. He is quite patently ensuring that we move as slowly as pressures will tolerate. We can forget about any comprehensive constitutional reform by 1988, our bicentenary year, as far as this Attorney-General is concerned. It was suggested in one of the national newspapers this morning that the Attorney-General plans to retire shortly. I have a great deal of respect for him as a man, but in terms of constitutional reform for this country the sooner he goes the better. Let us hope that he is replaced by somebody who is willing to fight for constitutional reform, particularly to set the goal of the bicentenary year for the achievement of major constitutional reforms in this country. God knows, we are well overdue in certain areas for constitutional reform.

One of the problems that we have suffered for decades-certainly my State of Western Australia has been suffering a great disadvantage-has been the precedence of State government rights over human rights, individual rights. Until this country gets a human rights Bill and human rights into the Constitution which give every Australian the right to go as far as the High Court of Australia to establish and to maintain his individual rights, we will have those rights stepped on by State governments. Of course, one recognises that the resistance to human rights legislation and reform starts with State governments which see that they may lose some of their power if the ordinary people, the individuals of this country, are given the same rights as ordinary people, as individuals, are given in most other countries in the Western world.
Another area of constitutional reform which was promised in 1983 by the Governor-General in his Speech on behalf of the Government was as follows:

My Government proposes to place before you a Bill for a referendum on fixed term parliaments, involving the setting of a fixed date for general elections to provide greater stability in the Australian political system.
That proposal was supported. The present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said in February 1983:
Under my Government, Parliaments will run their full term.

One would have thought that, having made that promise and commitment through the Governor-General's Speech, if there were to be a referendum it would be on fixed term parliaments. But no, that was thrown out by a weak-kneed government which bowed to the pressure of its own constituents and pressure groups within its own Party and dropped out the provision for a referendum on fixed term parliaments. It became obvious to us as 1984 went on that, following an election in 1983, the Prime Minister was going to call another election in 1984. So much for a commitment to parliaments running their full terms or to fixed term parliaments being put to the people by way of referendum!
Another reform which was promised but which has been left dangling from the 1983 Governor-General's Speech was the following:
Legislation will be introduced to ensure that the principle of one vote-one value is clearly established.

That promise is lying in limbo because the Government has failed to pick it up. There is no excuse for the Government's total inaction because the Australian Democrats, through Senator Michael Macklin of Queensland, introduced a Bill for one vote, one value. What did the Government do? It made darn certain that the Bill was never debated in this Parliament, never giving the Bill the opportunity to see the light of day in the Senate, because it is afraid to offend the Queensland Premier. It is afraid to offend the Premier of Queensland, who is probably renowned throughout the world as the leader of the gerrymander system. With another electoral redistribution due in the near future in Queensland, one can realise that there is a massive advantage inherent in that single Parliament, controlled by a minority representative group, ensuring that it is kept in parliament by fixing the boundaries, ensuring that people do not have a full value for each vote. I mentioned Queensland in particular because it was a Queensland senator who introduced that Bill, obviously with the objective of having it in place before the next Queensland election, before the next gerrymander could take place. But the Government abandoned its principle of one vote one value and the Australian Democrats' initiative to have that legislation in place before the next election.

Regrettably, in Western Australia we also suffer from malapportionment-from an inability of the people to have a full value for each vote. It is probably one of the greatest malapportionments left in the world. A person living out in certain country areas, not just rural areas but mining areas and others, may find that his vote for his State parliamentary representative is devalued to the point of being worth about one-fourteenth of a vote. That is simply not good enough and I now call upon the Government to get behind the reintroduced Bill, introduced for the second time by Senator Macklin of the Democrats, and to ensure that that legislation goes through as rapidly as possible to give all Australians equal value for their vote.

Pursuing the subject of electoral reform for a moment, I cannot understand why this Government is not willing to follow one of the most enlightened, fair and just electoral systems ever introduced anywhere in the world, and which is right here in Australia. The Hare-Clark system of Tasmania is a credit to the Government of Tasmania and the people of Tasmania. It serves them well. It ensures that in 95 per cent of cases people are represented in the Tasmanian Parliament by a person for whom they have voted; whereas somewhere between 40 per cent and 45 per cent of the people who vote for representatives for this Parliament do not have in the Parliament a representative for whom they have voted. A proportional representation system would ensure that in nearly every case they had somebody from their electorate with whom they could relate, somebody for whom they had voted, speaking and voting for them in the Federal Parliament.

Of course, what we have done is to move in exactly the opposite direction in this Parliament. The electoral reform system which was forced through in the previous Parliament to this one converted a reasonable proportional representation system for the Senate, the upper House in this Parliament, wherein five senators were elected at each half Senate election-an odd number, which is the imperative to proportional representation to make it a true proportional representation system-into a system in which six senators are elected at each half Senate election. Electing an even number virtually guarantees, if there are two evenly balanced reasonably strong political parties contesting the election, that they will get half of the seats each.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not always true.

—It is not always true, but the potential for it is there most of the time. The potential for a hung Senate is there most of the time. The intent was patently obvious to everyone who understands the voting system. The intent was to get rid of the minor parties, to get rid of the Australian Democrats, to ensure that we had only major parties in this Parliament. The people of Australia have shown that they reject that system. They not only have elected more Australian Democrats; they have in addition elected a representative from a new political party, and of course we still have an Independent in this House. That is a great thing for the democratic system. That democratic system will be in serious danger at the next and subsequent elections unless people recognise that without the Democrats and the Independents both Houses become a winner takes all Parliament. The effect of that is to revert not to a two party system but to a one party system for 999 days out of every 1,000 because only for one day in every 1,000 do the people have an opportunity to influence what takes place in this Parliament under that system. For the other 999 days the people are ignored if there are no Democrats or Independents in the Senate chamber. Now the people's voice is heard in this Parliament. Their influence is registered. Their influence moderates and modifies the extremists of the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal Party of Australia. It ensures that we do not go crazy in this Parliament because the extremists have control of the Caucus or the Liberal Party's committee.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many other areas of reform to which the Australian Democrats, and I believe most Australians, will be looking forward if the opportunity is given to us. We were promised tax reform. We have a tax system which is nearly half a century old. It is complex; it is imprecise and, frankly, much of the tax legislation is deliberately aimed at providing benefits and concessions. Some of those may be perceived by parliamentarians as quite legitimate and fair. Some of them are quite deliberate loopholes for friends of parliamentarians. But I believe there is a better system even for the legitimate concessions. We need tax reform to implement that better system because the existing system, with high marginal tax rates, encourages tax evasion and tax avoidance-legal tax avoidance. It introduces the subject of retrospective tax when those legal tax avoidance measures suddenly become quite immoral in the eyes of the community.

The tax legislation is in desperate need of reform. What are we going to do about it? We are going to have a tax summit, and I applaud that. I have already made my position and the Democrats' position very clear. We believe that the tax summit is a valuable first step. But if it is seen as the ultimate step we will not have tax reform; what we will have is more band-aids on the existing band-aids. Regrettably, we are already seeing Ministers backing away from real tax reform because there is no commitment to what follows the tax summit; no commitment for action. Whilst it is recognised that we need a comprehensive long term strategy, all that is being spoken about is: 'Let us have a consumption tax; let us shove that in the next Budget. Let us reduce personal income taxes. Let us make a few dramatic gestures; never mind about a comprehensive tax reform. Let us just see whether we can satisfy the majority of voters and as a result of that pretend that we have implemented tax reform'.

We will not get tax reform in this country without a commitment from all political parties. That commitment has to start now. It needs to commence with the tax summit. The tax summit needs to have representation from all political parties. We need to get rid of the pre-summit political point scoring by making it immoral for politicians to say what they will not accept at the tax summit, to put their own limits on the debate at the tax summit. Once that is taken away from politicians they will begin listening at the tax summit; they will tune in to the voice of Australia at the tax summit.

A joint parliamentary committee, representing all political parties, should be formed. We must get the commitment through the processes of the joint parliamentary committee, which is for all parliamentarians, all politicians and all political parties, to accept that there is a need for tax reform and then work towards it. Once there is the commitment the review system can commence and we can then take advantage of some wonderful and magnificent reports that are lying in dusty pigeon holes still waiting to be implemented. They are waiting for people to pick them up and run with them, make them have the effect that was designed when they were presented. I am talking about the magnificent reports of Asprey, Mathews, Campbell, Head and Groenewegen and also the reports from Meade of the United Kingdom and the Carter Commission of Canada. We can draw on the wisdom of other parts of the world that have similar problems to those which exist in Australia. We will have other inputs from the Economic Planning Advisory Council, the tax summit itself and the submissions that go to it and, of course, the Australian Commissioner of Taxation. All that information could be made available to a joint parliamentary committee which could share the responsibility for producing genuine long term tax reform in this country.

As I have already witnessed in my relatively short term in this Parliament, a joint parliamentary committee has the potential for taking party politics out of the parliamentary processes and for reaching a degree of consensus. More importantly, such a committee has the potential to resist pressure from vested interest groups and can come forward, following that, with genuine proposals for long term tax reform to which all political parties have a commitment. That gives us the potential for the tax reform that will take five years or perhaps 10 years to implement, but which will be genuine tax reform and not just band aid, ad hoc tax reform, which we have been getting for the last 50 years and which has just made the matter worse every time we suffer it.

The proposal that I now put forward to all parliamentarians is this: Let us start listening and stop shouting and rampaging around the country about what we want and what we will or will not accept. That does not preclude anybody-any individual, any pressure group or any political party-from saying that certain areas of tax reform are desirable. My own Party has a number of areas which we would like to have considered at the tax summit and by a joint parliamentary committee, but we are not going out on a limb and saying: 'This will be implemented or this will not be implemented over our dead bodies'. We want the debate to take place. We want it to be a reasoned debate. We do not want it to be a debate full of threats.

We have a number of areas of concern that have to be addressed. The whole subject of capital gains taxes-capital profits taxes might be a better way of describing them-has to be addressed. A number of acceptable exclusions from capital gains taxes are gradually evolving. We can take the fear out of people by universally accepting that there will be certain exclusions. The family home is an obvious one. We would like to see others. I am sure that other parties would like to have other areas introduced as exclusions. We need to recognise that until we modify our existing capital gains tax law-it is there already; it would not be something new-we leave the law open to the slick investors, because tax avoidance is their dream come true. They are growing fat under the existing system. They are able to manipulate their income into a capital income area and avoid paying any taxes at all. Of course, the by-product of that is that investments move into non-productive areas, such as land speculation, instead of areas which produce wealth for this nation.

We have a number of other areas of potential conflict. I believe we can achieve consensus out of the discussions. There is already a growing consensus for a consumption tax. I think there is still universal-if it is not universal it is darned near universal-acceptance out in the community at large, with the sole exception of politicians, that a consumption tax on the necessities of life is not acceptable. But let us look at that. People are saying: 'You can tax everything and compensate those who are hit by that tax on the necessities of life'. I have never seen such a system or such a theory put before me which could work, but let us talk about those things.

Rather than go through the whole schedule of potential areas for consideration in relation to tax reform, I will conclude with a couple of other suggestions for Government consideration, despite the fact that these items have been put forward by the Democrats in the form of private members' Bills. I appeal to the Government to pick up our private member's Bill for a register of foreign owned and controlled assets in this country. I believe there is concern in the community about the takeover of Australian assets by foreign owned and controlled corporations. Part of that fear is the unknown. The community at large is aware that not even the Government knows what proportion of this country is owned by overseas interests. Of course, until we have such a register moves such as the introduction of 16 foreign owned and controlled banks are frightening to many people. We need to know the degree of foreign ownership in this country.

We also have an urgent need to tidy up the whole area of tax avoidance. I introduced in this Parliament a tax avoidance schemes Bill which gives people a degree of certainty that they currently lack. They can register, through the Federal Treasurer, a tax avoidance proposal-it should really be called a tax minimisation proposal-and have it either approved or not approved. If the proposal is approved retrospective legislation against that proposal would be prohibited. If it is not approved it is open to retrospective legislation. There is a very fine line between tax avoidance and responsible business practice. We need to clarify where that line exists.

Finally, I put a further suggestion that the Government should look at reducing the cost of petrol in this country by changing the petrol pricing formula. The old formula was introduced for sound reasons, but I believe it has far outworn its usefulness in this country, except as a tax gathering mechanism. The people of Australia are now suffering under the system. I suggest that the formula be revised urgently, immediately, before the next price increase comes about as a result of an artificial formula which applies at present. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take just a moment to deal with a couple of matters to which Senator Jack Evans addressed his mind. He seemed to give rather fulsome support to having a Bill of Rights as a bicentennial project. It seemed to me that Senator Jack Evans was suggesting that the rights of individual Australian citizens would not be properly guaranteed unless such a Bill of Rights were passed through this Parliament or, indeed, it formed part of the Constitution. Without going into the relative comparison of the rights of individuals in Australian society or in the United Kingdom as compared with the rights of individuals in, for example, the United States of America, or to use an odious comparison, rights in the Soviet Union-which has a very interesting Bill of Rights-and without going into the question of what Senator Jack Evans means by rights, whether he means fundamental human rights, natural rights, or claims that are sometimes masqueraded as rights, I remind him that in 1973, the then Attorney-General, Senator Lionel Murphy, introduced a human rights Bill. That Bill somehow got lost in the hectic years of 1974-75, but an analysis of it indicated that it sought to implement the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, but with important differences. One change involved the family and its protection. Article 23 (1) of the Covenant states:

SPEECH.PARA: The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to protection by society and the State.

This matter was completely omitted by the Murphy Bill, as were certain provisions in Article 13, which protects parents' rights of freedom of choice in education. The 'right to life' in Article 6 of the Covenant also underwent some subtle rewriting. The question is: What type of Bill of Rights is required? But that is not the only question that should be addressed. We should also examine whether the passage of such legislation would unduly strike at the principle of near democracy; that is to say, that power in a democracy ideally should reside with those groups capable of efficiently performing the functions for which the power is acquired, so that those over whom the power is exercised have closer and more direct control over those who exercise it. In the instant case an overriding Bill of Rights could do just that; it could override certain rights which are traditionally those of State government authorities, State elected parliaments or elected municipal representatives. Of course, this would be striking at the principle of near democracy. I think we should be aware of that fact.

Naturally, one must balance the claim, in a democratic society, of 'the majority rules' with the importance of preserving the individual rights of the minority. Possibly the first duty of the majority in a democracy is to the preservation of the rights of the minority. We should also be concerned if a Bill of Rights extends the scope of the non-elected High Court of Australia to impose on the people judge-made laws relating to cherished values or social and community standards, and worse still, if it clothed the non-elected non-judicial Human Rights Commission or similar bodies with these powers, also accompanied by unprecedented investigative powers. I raise these as cautionary questions before we go overboard on a Bill of Rights.

Late last year I referred to the fact that the Attorney-General of the time had withdrawn certain reservations to an important treaty. Those reservations were withdrawn without reference to this Parliament or to the people-in fact, unbeknown to the people. It now appears-I believe this is the first time that this has been made public-as stated in the Australian Foreign Affairs Record, on page 1274, that the Commonwealth Government is considering:

. . . Australia becoming party to the Optional Protocol to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which gives individuals the right to take complaints of breaches of the Covenant directly to the United Nations Human Rights Committee after exhausting domestic remedies.

If that is the case, does that take out of the hands of Australia's democracies and institutions the ultimate control of where we are going and the ultimate responsibility that those institutions should have over the preservation of human rights in this society?

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that clause included or excluded?

—At present, under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, there is an optional protocol which, if it is signed by the treaty state, enables its citizens to go outside the jurisdiction of this country-for example, that of the High Court-and to appeal directly to the United Nations Human Rights Committee. Considering the composition of the United Nations Human Rights Committee, one would not want to allow it to define what human rights are in the first place. Certainly, any country would have to be careful about allowing such a body with such disparate views, some of its members coming from countries which systematically deny human rights, to determine the future of human rights in a country such as Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point I make is in respect of retrospective legislation. I have given the matter a great deal of consideration. Many unfounded accusations about tax avoidance and tax evasion practices have been hurled around over a fair period. My background makes those practices anathema to me. As Senator Jack Evans would appreciate, I voted to outlaw such practices, but I would not vote for legislation which applies a new tax retrospectively on the innocent and guilty alike. The question of certainty before the law is an important one for a democratic society. If we allow people to get away with imposing legislative retrospectivity, we allow any future government to engage in applying retrospectivity in ways contrary to the interests of the people about whom I am mainly concerned, the workers of Australia. For example, if we apply retrospectivity to legislation, we could enable State governments, or indeed the Commonwealth Government, to delete from workers compensation legislation scheduled injuries or scheduled diseases, retrospectively. Where does that leave the rights of individual workers?

I give an example that illustrates the ludicrous nature of such legislation. If a person blows in the breathalyser bag and is recorded as having an alcohol reading of 0.07 per cent when the legal limit is 0.08 per cent and the law then reduces the maximum limit to 0.05 per cent, that person does not expect the cops to go through the books and charge him for blowing into the bag with a 0.07 per cent alcohol reading. That is a clear example of the effect of retrospective legislation.

I turn to the Speech of the Governor-General. I deal particularly with the burning question of youth unemployment and the fact that consecutive governments have not really faced up to this problem. Before I elaborate on that, I note that Senator Aulich is in the chamber. I congratulate all new senators on their speeches. I note that Senator Aulich bemoaned the fact that we will have a new senator from Tasmania, Dr Norm Sanders. I point out to Senator Aulich that Dr Sanders will come to this Senate by kind favour of the Australian Labor Party in Tasmania by reason of the fact that the Tasmanian Labor Party allocated preferences to Dr Sanders. Kath Venn, a longstanding labor movement supporter, had over many years served this movement and the nation. She got the third highest vote of any candidate. What killed her was the block vote of the Labor Party going to a person who had destroyed the Labor Government in Tasmania.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to today's report that the United States Government has written to its North Atlantic Treaty Organisation allies and to other countries, including Australia, regarding possible participation in research as part of the strategic defence initiative. I also refer to reports on the midday Australian Broadcasting Corporation news that the Government will reject the invitation. I ask: Has the Government received the request from the United States and, if so, will the Minister provide details of the proposal? If not, is the knee-jerk reaction by the Government simply an attempt to head off a party brawl such as that which erupted at the time of the MX missiles crisis? Finally, why is the Government refusing to consider assisting in a program the aim of which is to eliminate eventually the threat posed by nuclear weapons by a movement to non-nuclear defensive systems?

—I am advised that the Government has not received an invitation from the United States to participate in research on the strategic defence initiative, SDI, although one may well be in the pipeline if today's Press reports are accurate. Since we have not received any such invitation, the question of accepting or rejecting it has not yet arisen, so the premise on which Senator MacGibbon constructed his question is not made out. I remind honourable senators, however, that as the Prime Minister stated in Washington on 7 February, the Government does not endorse the strategic defence initiative. I spelt out that same response in much more detail, giving reasons for it, in my answer in this place a few days ago-on 21 March. I also remind the honourable senator that the Government has sought and obtained on two occasions unqualified assurances from the United States that the joint facilities in Australia have no role in research undertaken under the SDI.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Health seen statements by the Tasmanian Minister for Health which blame the Federal Government's categorisations of private hospitals for the appallingly substandard situation at Ward H of the Queen Victoria Hospital in Launceston? Is the Minister also aware that the Tasmanian Minister for Health appears to be just as ignorant about construction matters as health matters, given his statements that there would be no need for a fire escape to be installed in that hospital as patients and staff could take the lifts in the case of a fire?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the reports in today's Tasmanian Press of Mr Cleary's remarks yesterday and they do not surprise me. I am waiting anxiously for the day when Mr Cleary blames the Federal Government for original sin in this country as he blames it for everything else. Of course we have a problem in Launceston, as we have in other parts of Australia, with people being unable to get their elderly relatives into nursing homes. In Launceston in particular we have the problem-again, it is shared by other parts of Australia-of acute hospital beds being used for long stay, geriatric type patients. For Mr Cleary to suggest that this situation has arisen because of the categorisation of private hospitals, and in particular the categorisation of St Luke's Hospital in Launceston, is nonsense and he knows it. This problem has existed in Launceston for many years and has been complained about by the Launceston General Hospital for at least five or six years.

ANSWER.PARA: The problem is not just that there is an insufficient number of nursing home beds. That is being corrected by the approval last year of funding for the Masonic Nursing Home in Launceston. The problem is an Australia-wide problem. We have more nursing home beds per capita in this country than is the case anywhere else in the world, we probably spend less per capita on domiciliary care than is spent anywhere else in the world, and too many people are in nursing homes when they should not be there and nursing homes are the most expensive form of accommodation for the aged. I believe that this is known to everyone in this chamber. What we need to do is to get the co-operation of the State governments, the Federal Government and the non-government organisations which run the nursing homes to ensure that their admission policies are such that only people who need nursing home care go into nursing homes, that people who improve in nursing homes are able to be discharged-at the moment it tends to be a one-way street-and that we all co-operate in changing our policy so that the policy is a more appropriate one for the needs of the aged in this country.

I found Mr Cleary's comment about the problems at Ward H extraordinary. I knew that he would blame the Federal Government, as he always does, but for a Minister for Health in this country to suggest that it is perfectly all right not to have fire escape provisions in a six-storey hospital because, in the case of a fire, people can get into a lift and go down demonstrates his ignorance. He must be blind. I think that every lift in this country has a sign on it stating: 'Do not use in case of fire'. I hope that Mr Cleary is the one who leads the charge to the lift when a fire starts in the Queen Victoria Hospital.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FORWARD ESTIMATES OF INCOME AND EXPENDITURE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. In light of the need for the community to understand the difficulties and the necessity for restraint in government expenditure, will the Minister release the details of the forward estimates of income and expenditure for 1985-86, as the Government did for 1983-84?

—Only one of those estimates is my responsibility, that is, the estimates of outlays, and I do have a tentative intention of releasing details of them in May. The other matter that the honourable senator raised concerns the Treasurer and I will refer the question to him.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I ask this question of Senator Grimes rather than Senator Ryan because Senator Grimes, while he may lack expertise in sport, has expertise in the consequences of sport. Has the Minister seen in a book called The Exercise Myth by Dr Henry Solomon claims that exercise can be dangerous? Will the Minister comment on the claims made by Dr Solomon that exercise can lead to sudden death? Further, does the Minister agree that such reports are grist for the mill for those who are only too willing to remain sedentary, lazy, devoted to the soft life or merely defensive on this issue, and that they also create anxiety and/or fear in the community based on significant misinformation and insufficient analysis?
—I hope that the Minister representing the Minister for Health will give a short-winded reply.

—That is very easy for me, Mr President. One of the pleasures of coming to this Parliament early in the morning is that one either passes Senator Crowley running across the bridge or sees her in her exercise gear as she comes out of the women's-I think it is-exercise class in which people take part of a morning.
—That is sexist.
—Like Senator Withers, I am one who is well aware of the dangers of exercise. One has only to look at the photographs of the Prime Minister taken after a cricket match earlier this year.
—And Senator Withers at the Thredbo barbeque.

—I think that comment is most unkind. The profile shot of Senator Withers at the Thredbo barbecue should have been censored from the newspapers. I think the short answer to Senator Crowley's question is this: Exercise is sometimes good and sometimes bad for us. For someone such as Senator Crowley, who has been exercising all her life, it is obviously a good thing but if Senator Withers and I took up jogging all of a sudden there may well be a necessity for the State governments of Tasmania and Western Australia to replace us very soon. Most things in moderation are good, according to my medical colleagues, and things in excess are bad-not only exercise. It is quite obvious that some of the publicity about the need for exercise has upset people's consciences so much that they have gone out and immediately tried to be marathon runners. Those are the people who, I believe, end up in the mortuary very quickly. I do not think that the book referred to, and certainly the articles that I read on that book, are harmful to the cause of the fitness fanatics in this country, such as Senator Crowley. What we need is a balanced argument. Whatever we think about it there will always be people like Senator Crowley who do a lot of running and keep fit and there will always be people like Senator Withers and me who are more cerebral types and who exercise our minds more than our bodies.
—You mean you think about exercising!

—Senator Withers and I think a lot about exercising. I think that, as long as the balance is kept and the facts as they are delivered are correct and not biased, we will end up with a balanced argument. However, I am afraid that it will not make much difference to what any of us do.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Is the Minister for Defence aware of operations entitled 'Busy Boomerang' and 'Glad Customer' which involve B52 bombers in Darwin as part of the United States strategic offensive force? What do these operations involve? Will they continue when the B52s are fitted with cruise missiles as part of the United States strategic modernisation program in the coming year? Is the Government aware of the fact that the newer B52Gs will carry short range attack missiles? Will the B1s, known as 'stealth bombers', be part of these operations in Australia? Can the Government give an undertaking that operations Busy Boomerang and Glad Customer involve only non-armed bombers? If this is the case and they are part of the bomber base activities at Guam, where are the bombs unloaded before they enter Australia at Darwin?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have before me a full briefing on this matter from the Minister for Defence and it may be necessary to supplement what I say on a later occasion in order to give Senator Chipp a full answer. In terms of what I am able to tell him, I can say in relation to Operation Glad Customer that, under a 1981 agreement, and subject to individual approval, B52 aircraft carry out low level navigation training over Queensland, land at Darwin and then undertake sea surveillance and navigation training over the Indian Ocean.

ANSWER.PARA: Under Operation Busy Boomerang Delta, pursuant to a 1982 agreement, and again subject to individual approval, B52 aircraft carry out low level navigation training over Queensland, land at Darwin and subsequently conduct more low level training over selected low jet routes in the Northern Territory and Western Australia. The United States is not prepared to disclose which of its aircraft are nuclear-armed and which are armed with conventional weapons. Its policy in this respect is identical to that which prevails in relation to ships. Our current arrangements for B52 flights through Darwin are, however, an extension of the low level navigation training flights approved by the Minister for Defence in late 1979 when it was agreed-and I am sure that Senator Chipp will remember this-they would be unarmed and carry no bombs. It is certainly the Government's clear understanding that that is the basis on which those two operations continue to be carried out. I will get further more detailed information from the Minister for Defence if he is able to offer it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that reply and for his undertaking. I could not hear perfectly some sections of his answer so I ask a supplementary question in this form: Can he give me a guarantee that the Government is certain that up to this point no B52 has flown over Australian soil loaded with nuclear bombs?

—All I can say is that it is our understanding that any flights over Australia are being conducted pursuant to the agreement of 1979 which is that such flights would be unarmed and certainly carry no nuclear bombs. We believe that the United States is not in the habit of breaching agreements of this kind and I imagine on that basis I could give Senator Chipp the guarantee he seeks. However, I will ask the Minister for Defence whether he wishes to add anything to that answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to a report in the Age newspaper of 23 March in which the Director-General of the Australian Natural Disasters Organisation disputed a claim based on United States military documents obtained under freedom of information provisions that security procedures established by the Pentagon to clean up after a nuclear accident in foreign countries would exclude local authorities. Can the Minister inform the Senate whether procedures for cleaning up after a nuclear accident involving United States nuclear armed and/or powered vessels in Australian ports have been agreed to by Australian and American authorities; whether local authorities are to be involved in these clean up procedures; and whether local authorities in cities visited by United States warships currently have detailed plans for dealing with such accidents or emergencies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will give Senator McIntosh such information as I possess, which is not much. On the first point, the United States has accepted absolute liability for any nuclear damage which might result from a nuclear incident involving the reactor of a United States warship. Australia expects that this will involve full co-operation in assisting with clean-up procedures, including assistance with radiation monitoring and decontamination. Australia would expect similar assistance in the event of a nuclear weapons accident. These matters are the subject of continuing dialogue with the United States. I add, of course, that this is contingency planning of the highest order and no one anticipates that any such accident will occur.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question of local authorities' involvement, the situation is that State authorities would co-ordinate responses to nuclear accidents. However, the Commonwealth Government would provide assistance in the form of capabilities for radiation monitoring, decontamination and related clean-up activities. As to the question about local authorities' current plans for dealing with such accidents, the situation again is that safety planning for foreign ship visits or anything of that kind is the responsibility of State and Territory governments rather than the Commonwealth. Within those jurisdictions, organisations have developed specific plans to cover nuclear reactor accidents. It is my understanding, as briefed by the relevant Minister, that nuclear weapons accidents are covered in general State and Territory plans for emergencies and disasters. I believe that is an answer to Senator McIntosh's question, but if there are any further and better particulars that I can give him about the nature of such plans, I will make further inquiries and see what I can do.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Is it correct, as reported today, that the Minister's proposal for reintroduction of tertiary fees would have returned about $230m a year to Commonwealth revenue? Does yesterday's Caucus rejection of tertiary fees pose a significant budgetary problem for the Government and can the Minister say where he might look to raise the extra revenue?

—The amount of revenue which would be raised by applying a charge depends obviously on the degree of cost recovery which was sought and the level of exemptions. One can get any figure one likes from that between zero and about $2,000m. There is no precise answer to the first part of the question. As to the second part, obviously there are a number of proposals for reducing expenditure or raising revenue. If some of the options are closed off, the others must be pursued in a more disciplined and rigid way. It is not for me to say at this stage where the alternatives will be found, but given the strong opposition to the charging of tertiary fees expressed by at least four state governments I expect that the States will be willing to take their share of the penalty and the consequences of the policies that they have been advocating.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Science. Has he seen a report in the Adelaide News of last Friday referring to Antarctica and headed 'Mawson Huts must be Restored'? What has been the role of the Commonwealth in the restoration of these historic huts, built by Sir Douglas Mawson in the Antarctic at the turn of the century, and has any recent approach been made to the Commonwealth Government for funds to subsidise the cost of chartering a vessel to go to the Antarctic to restore these huts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Press article in question has been drawn to my attention. Let me say first that the article arises from the putting together of a private expedition called Project Blizzard, which is planning to restore Mawson's hut but which would seek government assistance with shipping costs in carrying out that initiative. Project Blizzard inspected Mawson's hut at Commonwealth Bay last December and January to assess the condition of the building and artefacts, and assistance was provided for that initiative by the Antarctic Division of the Department of Science. A preliminary report from Project Blizzard indicates that the hut appears not to have deteriorated significantly since an Antarctic Division group inspected it in 1978. However, the need for conservation work will be assessed on the basis of Project Blizzard's detailed report, which is expected in June.

ANSWER.PARA: It is most unlikely that resources would be available to assist with the charter of a vessel solely for Project Blizzard's activities; that is, for the private initiative. The diversion of an Antarctic Division vessel to Commonwealth Bay would be very expensive, given that the area is so far off our normal shipping routes. I am unable to give a final answer on this question because the Minister is scheduled to meet with expedition organisers early next month and presumably from that discussion some agreed, or otherwise, position will arise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Resources and Energy consulted with his State and Territory colleagues about the Federal Government's proposal to introduce a system of cash bonus bidding for oil exploration permits? If so, has he asked them to consider the application of the system to waters adjacent to the State or Territory in which they are interested? What is their attitude to this proposal and why was it impertinent, as Senator Walsh said in the Senate yesterday, for the Premier of Western Australia to express a view in relation to this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some initial consultation with the States has taken place, most recently at the Australian Minerals and Energy Council meeting in New Zealand just a few days ago. The views of the States on this matter were expressed. They vary in intensity, but in respect of all of them it is obvious that a degree of further consultation will be necessary before we go down the path of introducing cash bidding for the allocation of acreages in State-adjacent or Northern Territory-adjacent areas. I made it clear in an announcement a couple of weeks ago on the Timor Sea releases that the Commonwealth has quite deliberately at this stage proposed cash bidding releases only in an area that is wholly and solely within the Commonwealth's area of legal competence, as the legislation now stands-not as the constitutional situation now stands, but under the legislation. It is in everybody's interest to wait and see what the outcome of that first round of bidding is in that particular environment before pressing the matter so far as the States are concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: I did note what Premier Burke had to say two days ago at the Western Australian conference. I also noted what my colleague Senator Walsh had to say yesterday in this place. It needs to be appreciated that Senator Walsh and Mr Burke have been close friends and colleagues for many years and it would be quite presumptuous of me to contradict any description Senator Walsh might offer of his friend. Indeed, it may well be that in Western Australia the terms used are terms of endearment; they certainly seem to throw them around often enough. Of course, when Mr Burke spoke he was labouring under the disability of not having heard or read the speech I made in Perth yesterday afternoon. I am sure that when he does so it will make impossible any claim of ignorance that one might be minded to make about his understanding of these issues and I am sure that impertinence will be the furthest thing from his mind when he is so armed with this information.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am wondering whether Senator Evans's reference in his speech yesterday to Mr Burke as Attila the Hun is likely to encourage Mr Burke's support for him.

—Again in context that has to be understood as a term of endearment. I did in fact say that I thought he was a little too plump to play the role of Attila the Hun but in every other respect he would be perfectly well cast. If Senator Durack happened to read the transcript of that ad lib section of my speech, he would react as calmly as apparently Mr Burke has to the noises that I then made.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Community Services. What progress has been made in the establishment of an Office of Aged Care?
—Did that question surprise you?

—It did, actually. In establishing my new Department, combining those aspects of the Department of Social Security dealing with services and the nursing home sections of the Department of Health, we are establishing an Office of Aged Care. Three problems have to be resolved at the moment, but I believe that they will be resolved very quickly. The first point is that I must go to my colleague on my right, Senator Walsh, and get sufficient staff for the new Department. Secondly, the new Head of the Department, Mr Codd, is drawing up with me a new departmental structure. Thirdly, obviously we will need to recruit staff for the Office of Aged Care. I suppose that a fourth question is whether that office should be in Canberra or in, say, Sydney or Melbourne, where the people we are dealing with actually are.

—I ask the Minister for Finance whether it is a fact that the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust withdrew from a proposed 15 per cent investment stake in the Alcoa of Australia Ltd Portland smelter. Was this due to the obsessive secrecy provisions of the Cain Government's Alcoa (Portland Aluminium Smelter) Amendment Bill, which prevents adequate disclosure of the viability of the project, or was it because the project's viability is now open to serious question due to the attitude displayed by the Cain Government? Finally, has the Victorian Government sought Australian Loan Council approval to borrow the additional $260m overseas, or will the Federal Government give consideration to bailing out Mr Cain just as it came to the rescue of the Burke Government over the North West Shelf project?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that Senator Lewis drew the analogy between the Cain and Burke governments in this respect because I was about to do that myself. They were both victims of stupid decisions made by the previous Liberal governments in Victoria and Western Australia respectively. The Western Australian Government was confronted with a prospective deficit in actual dollar terms of several billion dollars-billion dollars, not million dollars-because of the natural gas contract which Charlie Court forced the State Electricity Commission of Western Australia to sign back in 1980 and which left the SEC with no market for about 40 per cent of the gas it contracted to buy. What is more, if I may say so, Charlie Court insisted on adding, completely gratuitously, another 12.5 per cent on to that contract when he was not required by the joint venturers to do so. In the case of the Victorian Government, a lot of capital was sunk into the Portland smelter before the Cain Government came to office. The Cain Government inherited that difficult situation; it was not responsible for it. As far as I know it has coped with that very difficult inheritance as well as any government could reasonably be expected to do.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Lewis asked whether the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust had withdrawn from the project. I do not think 'withdrawn' is really the correct word. The SFIT was contemplating taking some equity in the project and three months ago, I believe, it decided that it would not take equity in it. The fund is now regarded by the Government as autonomous. There is some legislation to go through the Parliament, but I certainly regard it as autonomous, as my predecessor did. Therefore, I do not believe it is my duty to inquire into the investment policy of the members of the trust or to demand to know from them the reasons why they did or did not make any particular investment. The Government's attitude is that, providing the trust complies with the provisions of its enabling legislation-in other words, stays within the law-what it does is its own affair, because it is responsible only for contributors' money, not for government money per se. To my knowledge an application from the Victorian Government for Loan Council approval for extra borrowings has not been made, but I will see whether the Treasurer has anything to add.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Last week I asked the Minister a question on wine sales in Australia since the imposition of a 10 per cent sales tax in last year's Budget. Since then have any new figures on wine sales become available? If new figures have been released, do they show a drop in wine sales due to the tax? Do any new figures support the dire predictions of the Opposition that a wine tax would ruin the Australian wine industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some new figures have come to light. The sales of Australian wine for the month of January were published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics yesterday. Senator Cook asked me whether they support the dire predictions made by assorted members of the Opposition last year. The answer is no, they do not support those predictions. Indeed, they flatly contradict them and show how stupidly erroneous and irresponsible were the predictions made by the Opposition. Sales for the month of January 1985, compared to January 1984, were up by 5 per cent. That compares to a year on year growth in the year before the sales tax on wine was introduced of 4.1 per cent, so sales are increasing at a faster rate than they were increasing prior to the imposition of the 10 per cent tax. In view of Senator Cook's reference to the claims and stupid, irresponsible assertions made by assorted members of the Opposition last year, I have a few quotations. Senator Messner, on 23 August last year said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . as a result of the introduction of this tax there will be a decline of 13 1/2 per cent of its total market.
Senator Jessop said:
A 10 per cent sales tax on wine will automatically lead to a decrease of aobut 21 per cent in the grape crush of growers.

That is the most extreme claim I could find anywhere. Senator Hill said that there would be more than 4,000 jobs lost in South Australia; that South Australian wine growers would lose $15m in income and that the Riverland growers would lose $5m in income. Senator Teague said that the impact of the higher price to the consumer because of the sales tax would lead to a drop in consumption estimated to be 14 per cent. In other words, they showed appalling judgment. They tried to scare the daylights out of wine grape growers in the wine industry, just as they try to scare the daylights out of pensioners or anybody else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister is debating the question. I suggest he bring his answer to a conclusion.

—In summary, I say-in response to Senator Cook's question-that the facts have shown that all the members of the Opposition were widely wrong and, indeed, what they were saying was nothing short of palpable nonsense.

—I refer the Minister for Finance to the statements by him relating to the Commonwealth contribution to local government financing. What effect does the Minister expect that the slashing of Federal Government funds to local government authorities will have on local government rates and charges? Contrary to the Minister's statement to the Senate on Monday that 'local government authorities have not increased their revenue raising effort', local government taxation has increased from 1.21 per cent of gross domestic product in the year 1980-81 to 1.28 per cent of gross domestic product in the year 1982-83, which last-mentioned figure is, according to the Minister's Department, the most recent available. I ask further: Does not this proposal of the Minster simply represent an attempt to shift the tax burden so that the Federal Government will appear on paper to be conforming to its trilogy commitments?

—To my knowledge, nobody has talked about or contemplated slashing funding to local government. To my knowledge, nobody has talked or thought about anything less than an increase in real terms in the amount of money that is likely to be paid to local government next year compared to this year. What has yet to be decided is the size of that real terms increase. Senator Peter Rae seems to be implying that there ought to be a 15 per cent real terms increase to local government. If he believes that, I wonder whether he also believes that there should be a 15 per cent increase in real terms in payments to the States and, if not, why not.
—I did not mention 15 per cent, or any other.

—He did not say it, but he was implying it. I am not familiar with the figures he quoted. I make the general observation that it is possible to get movements in figures if a particular starting date and finishing date are selected. On Monday I said-if I did not say it, I certainly intended to-that local governments have not increased rating income in accordance with the rise in property values. When property values are rising in real terms, that means economic rent is accruing to land because of its scarcity value. I do not see anything wrong with taxing some of that economic rent with high rates. In other words, the Henry Georgists, although they saw only a tiny section of reality, insofar as they did see it, correctly identified it. I see nothing wrong with taxing the economic rent which accrues to land because of its increasing scarcity value or its value as a positional good.

—I have a supplementary question. I ask the Minister to address the question I asked him, which was not related in any way to increases in the value of land, but rather to local government taxation as a percentage of gross domestic product, which must take into account the movements in the economy, including increases in value. I suggested that in the two-year period for which the latest figures are available there was an increase in the percentage of GDP from 1.21 to 1.28 per cent in taxation by local government. Does that not represent an increase in the taxation effort of local government as a percentage of GDP?

—If the figures are correct, of course it does; that is undeniable. However, it does not address the point that land values can increase at a faster rate than nominal growth. Under that situation I see nothing wrong with rates on land increasing as a proportion of GDP.

—Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen the most recent figures from the Australian Statistician on retail sales? Do these figures indicate anything about the likelihood of achieving the Budget forecasts on consumer spending?

—For the three months ended January, retail sales, which it is true had been sluggish for a considerable time, were 8.1 per cent higher than they had been for the corresponding period of the previous year or after the implicit price deflator had been applied, represented an increase in real terms of 3 per cent or just above. That piece of good news was supplemented today with some very good figures regarding motor vehicle registrations which have, for the three months ended February, been running at an annual rate of very close to 700,000 a year, which is almost up to the peak level which they hit early in 1975. They are almost running at an all-time record level. After running through most of the years of the Fraser Government at a level of somewhere between 550,000 and 580,000 they are now running at an annual rate of almost 700,000.
—We are going well.

—This is due, as Senator Button suggests, to the growing confidence in the community. This Government is managing the economy very well and the people have come to realise it. Those figures on retail sales suggest that the Budget time forecast for private consumption expenditure, which from memory was 2.75 per cent, is likely to be exceeded. In addition to that, since the National Economic Summit Conference was held in April 1983, some 360,000 new jobs have been created and the rate of unemployment has fallen to 8.3 per cent, despite some increase in the participation rate. Perhaps most gratifying of all is the recent surge in private investment. In the December quarter of 1984, compared with the December quarter of 1983, investment in real terms had increased by 9.4 per cent. The estimate for 1985-86 is some 24 per cent higher than the corresponding estimate for 1984-85. So, both in general and in the specifics, the answer is yes, the Budget time expectations of growth in consumption sales are being more than realised. Indeed all the economic indicators of growth, unemployment, investment and so on show that all the Government's expectations have been equalled or exceeded.

—I ask the Minister for Finance: Does the Minister deny that Mr Brian Toohey, editor of the National Times, is correct when he says that a telephone conversation that he had with Senator Walsh was tapped and that allegedly critical comments made by the Minister about his Prime Minister were passed on to Mr Hawke?

—Mr President, I am not going to discuss that matter because I believe it would be improper for me to do so. I can suggest to Senator Puplick, since he has an interest in the possibility of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation tapping telephones and then, quite improperly and illegally, passing on information from security files to use for domestic political purposes--
—Did they do that?

—I am about to come to that. I suggest that Senator Puplick ask his colleague Mr Coleman, MP, who in 1970 or 1971 was flogging around to journalists ASIO files which contained damaging allegations about assorted people in the Australian Labor Party to see whether he could persuade the journalists to publish them. I refer the honourable senator to an article in the National Times, I think about two years ago, and an Australian Broadcasting Commission Four Corners program in 1971, when the facts regarding that were set out by a particular person--
—Did you bucket your Leader to Toohey?
—Senator Chipp should go and send some more conscripts up to Vietnam. That is what he was best at-sending conscripts up to Vietnam. He has the blood of 500 Australians on his hands.
—Order! Senator Walsh, I ask you to answer the question directed to you by Senator Puplick.

—Certainly, Mr President. I will not be distracted again by the interjections of the man who was a Minister in the McMahon Government which sent 500 Australians to their death in Vietnam. I am not going to answer Senator Puplick's question, Mr President; it would be quite improper for me to do so. If he is interested in the subject of the misuse by ASIO operatives, for domestic political purposes, of intelligence information, I suggest he take up the subject with his colleague Mr Coleman MP, who the record shows is an expert on the matter and on so misusing, or attempting to misuse, security information. Somebody has just handed me a copy--
—Order! I suggest the Minister withdraw that imputation against a member of another House.
—In deference to you I will, Mr President. Nevertheless, the fact remains that I have the National Times article with me here and I table it.
—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President.

—On a point of order, Mr President, before the supplementary question, I suggest that if it is out of order to make the statement it is equally out of order to table the statement, and that the tabling of the statement should be withdrawn.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Mr President, you ruled out of order the Minister's statement. Surely there are two ways of making a statement in this place-one is verbally; the other is by tabling a document. Tabling the document which apparently was being used by the Minister was an alternative way of breaching your ruling. The Minister is making a statement by using a document which, apparently, contains a statement which the Minister previously quoted.

—Order! The Minister made an imputation against another member of this Parliament. Under standing order 418 I asked him to withdraw that imputation. He did.
